text: A muzzle report uh typically associated
with the sound that a gun makes. It's
the report of the muzzle, the bang.
But in this case, muzzle report is the
just the cool name actually we gave to a
piece of custom hardware that we
developed for uh the lost chapter is
predominantly constructed of 3D printed
plastic and on that chassis that 3D
printed chassis is micro electronics
based on Arduino and offtheshelf
sensors, wires and components that you
know anyone could really pick up. And
what muzzle report is doing is detecting
the gas leaving the barrel and it's
[music] reporting that data into Unreal
and allowing us to have effectively a
digi double of that gun firing.
For muzzle report, what I did was take a
plugin that already exists in the engine
called Open Track IO and adapt it to uh
listen to the messages that the muzzle
report sends. So when the muzzle report
sends a message over the network, what
it's doing is it's sending a string that
contains the name of the gun, how many
shots are fired, the battery level. The
bit that we're most interested in is how
many shots have been fired. So
fundamentally the live link subject um
at each frame uh reads [music] the
number of shots that have been fired and
then the blueprint that listens to that
subject when it uh registers that the
number of shots fired has changed knows
that that is when we should um fire a
bullet into the scene we should trigger
the muzzle uh flash uh effects. We
should trigger the bullet holes and the
bullet hits. [music] And so that's how
we get a message from the physical gun
to the gun in the game.
[screaming]
>> It was like I was genuinely in the world
of Kill Bill with all those set pieces
and I could also interact with it within
my own space. So it was kind of the best
of both worlds where I could have all
those physical elements and then also
see how it was going to look in the
world itself.
So the thing that excites me about a
device like Muzzle Report [music] is
that it is interactive and it's in real
time and it's in the actor's hands and
it becomes part of their performance. So
along with the facial animation and the
body animation, the fact that [music]
we're able to see everything in real
time um and the director and the
creatives can respond to a performance
immediately um [music] I think just
makes the whole business of performance
capture much more exciting. [music]
